body: ### Problem steps to reproduce: 1. enable non "box" extui 2. run a long command with lots of output, such as `:verbose map` (the more mappings you have, the easier to see) 3. while the output scrolls, the "box" panel of extui briefly shows, then it also shows the normal "pager", then the "box" disappears ``` nvim --clean --cmd "lua require('vim._extui').enable({})" :verbose map ```

comment_data.body:
It's specifically "verbose"-kind messages that are routed to the box (now "msg") window. Mainly to not render the the editor mostly useless with `:set verbose=9`, showing each executed autocmd.

The `:verbose map` example here is not ideal, it obviously doesn't make sense to separate the verbose message from its mapping. Maybe we should just not assign it the verbose kind internally (and for similar commands).

oh `nvim -V9` is a fantastic demo of the no-press-enter behavior.



> routed to the box (now "msg") window. Mainly to not render the the editor mostly useless with `:set verbose=9`, showing each executed autocmd.

I don't understand why, that sounds like we have 2 different pagers. but maybe i lack sleep...

The "box" (which was renamed to "msg"?) really doesn't seem necessary. 

- We should rename `"cmd"`, to `"msg"`, and drop the separate "box" concept (currently called `"msg"`). 
    - By default message area happens to overlay the cmdline, but that is an implementation detail.
    - Then we can drop `target` field.
- The timed "fade out" behavior can be enabled by setting `timeout`.
    - Disabled by default. (By default, the messages area should behave as the current `target='cmd'` behaves.)
- Users can customize placement of the msg area by handling an event, something like `:autocmd FileType msg call nvim_win_set_config(0, ...)`.

> The "box" (which was renamed to "msg"?) really doesn't seem necessary.

It is for `cmdheight=0` (and for people who prefer the "notifier" plugins, of which there are many).

Why does it need to be a separate filetype? The positioning, dimensions, and "timed fade out" behavior are just things that users can tweak. It doesn't require a different "box" concept. 

We only need one "messages area", not multiple. Its size, position, etc, are things that users can customize.

And for `cmdheight=0` it's 100% arbitrary that we would just decide to randomly place the messages area over the buffer instead of in the normal place.

We do, because we want to have _different_ output in _different_ areas (long-form `:Inspect` output, notifications, progress). No matter what you call it, there must be different parallel output routes.

> we want to have _different_ output in _different_ areas (long-form `:Inspect` output, notifications, progress)

Then why is `target` set to only one or the other? 

Long-form output is navigable via the "pager" (i.e. when `g<` focuses the messages area).

I don't understand why we need two separate builtin "message area" things, instead of a single one that can be customized.

In the screenshot I showed above, it makes no sense that some messages are in two different places.
Sorry, it's clear to me now that the plan changed (again) in the middle of implementation. I will not interfere further.

> the plan changed (again) in the middle of implementation

Things do change as new knowledge is discovered. And we intentionally don't (yet) have test coverage for this work, because we anticipated rapid adaptation as we discover things.

The plan I've been working from has always been ["kill press enter"](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/1029) and ["truncate and show a +n"](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/1029#issuecomment-2848852784).

I see that https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/22478 mentions "allowing Nvim (and plugins etc) to better decide ... which messages need a pager [and] which should fade away after some time", so I guess that's what you're referring to.

The metadata (such as message `kind`) mentioned in #22478 is still present, nothing has been lost or changed. And as mentioned above, the "fade away" behavior can be toggled-on.

But introducing another message area was never a required part of the "plan", unless there is some other outline I've missed. The door is open for doing that later, or for plugins to do it using the enhanced metadata. But the first phase of @luukvbaal's work doesn't need to involve that. I've been extremely consistent since the start, that "phase 1" of this work should show messages in the cmdline area, while keeping the door open *in later phases* for other UI choices.

> I don't understand why we need two separate builtin "message area" things, instead of a single one that can be customized.

The fact that one of the currently supported options shares the 'cmdheight' area complicates that. Moving it to a separate window isn't just a case of customizing the cmdline window. That's why the dedicated message area is a separate window/filetype.

A lot of work has gone into the "msg" target (I implemented it first after deciding that completely mimicking the message grid would be unfeasible/unwanted, but the cmdline target has progressed nicely and both seem useful to me now). Dropping it from the module at this point seems unnecessary, it just shouldn't be used by default.

> In the screenshot I showed above, it makes no sense that some messages are in two different places.

The reason for it is mentioned here:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/bff7d3fd9f20fe8f8373844454181550dc6ba05d/runtime/lua/vim/_extui/messages.lua#L362-L365

But obviously that doesn't hold for "last set" messages that should be kept with its source. It's questionable anyhow with how the cmdline message target has progressed. Even `nvim -V9` seems usable enough with it now. So yeah it should be fine to remove the above if-statement.

> So yeah it should be fine to remove the above that if-statement.

Yeah that may be all that's needed. Sorry for the confusion. 

The `target` field led me to believe that these message areas were just different layouts for the same concept. Should we drop the `target` field, and instead guide users to customize these windows/buffers via FileType handlers?

> because we want to have _different_ output in _different_ areas (long-form `:Inspect` output, notifications, progress).

I misunderstood what @clason meant here. Yes, "notifications" are different than messages. The traditional Vim example of "notifications" is 'ruler', 'showcmd', and we obviously will expand that (e.g. maybe "progress" belongs there).

But there is still something I don't get: if the "box" is for ephemeral messages ("notifications"), does that conflict with the idea that some users will want to use it for all messages + notifications? Or if that's not a conflict, then would it make sense  to use the cmdline area as the default for both ?

> The target field led me to believe that these message areas were just different layouts for the same concept. Should we drop the target field, and instead guide users to customize these windows/buffers via FileType handlers?

In my eyes they are, one is the cmdline window, the other a dedicated message window. Further customization of them may be possible through FileType handlers but I don't see how we could drop the target logic (granted that it won't be used by default).

> Or if that's not a conflict, then would it make sense to use the cmdline area as the default for both ?

Don't think it is a conflict no. And yes, I think we would use the cmdline area for both by default (like vim.notify already just nvim_echo's by default).

> one is the cmdline window, the other a dedicated message window.

But why? The default positioning of the messages should be in the "cmdline" area, but that is just a default presentation decision. It happens to overlay the cmdline and use 'cmdheight' (which we could change later e.g. by introducing 'messageheight'). But it is still just the "messages area" conceptually. 

We should not have two different "message area" concepts. We should have one "messages area", and users can adjust the position, etc.

> It happens to overlay the cmdline and use 'cmdheight'

Thing is that it doesn't just overlay the cmdline. Right now the messages and cmdline share the same buffer/window with `target = 'cmd'`. Always using a separate message window whose position/timeout can be customized like you suggest might be simpler conceptually. Not sure it would make the implementation easier. Would complicate things with the ruler/showcmd at least, having to route it to a different window depending on whether the cmdline or a message was last shown. Would have to try it out.

> Always using a separate message window whose position/timeout can be customized like you suggest might be simpler conceptually. Not sure it would make the implementation easier. Would complicate things with the ruler/showcmd at least

Don't we have to solve that implementation challenge anyways, if we are going to support the "box" placement?
Currently it's always placed in the cmdline window. The challenge changes if we suddenly start drawing the message window _over_ the cmdline window.

Ok. I'm trying out `cmdheight=0`. It feels pretty good. The notifications popup behaves well, and probably is something we want to enable by default, for things that are definitely notifications.

I notice that `:ls` shows in the cmd area while `:!ls` shows in the notifications area. The notifications popup will be useful for some things, but probably not shell output?

It's not really clear why `verbose`, `:echom`, etc., are treated like notifications. The effect is kind of random. 

My suggestion would be to treat almost everything like non-notifications, except if the caller "opts in" by setting a `nvim_echo` flag or something. And furthermore, we could let users configure which message `kind`s they want to always go to the notifications popup. Allowing users to set a `kind` list avoids blocking Nvim 0.12 release while we debate which things go where.

WDYT?

>  I notice that :ls shows in the cmd area while :!ls shows in the notifications area. The notifications popup will be useful for some things, but probably not shell output?
It's not really clear why verbose, :echom, etc., are treated like notifications. The effect is kind of random.

There is no well defined notifications concept yet, so nothing is treated as such per se. Since there is no cmdline area with 'cmdheight' = 0, _all_ regular messages are shown in the dedicated message window. The only exceptions are `list_cmd` and interactively typed `echo/lua_print` kinds, which we assume should be shown indefinitely. Since the dedicated message window has a timeout, they are routed to the pager. That's the only logic behind it currently, no classification of a notification kind.

And yes, shell output should probably be routed to the pager as well. Configurable routing sounds useful.

> My suggestion would be to treat almost everything like non-notifications, except if the caller "opts in" by setting a `nvim_echo` flag or something. And furthermore, we could let users configure which message `kind`s they want to always go to the notifications popup. Allowing users to set a `kind` list avoids blocking Nvim 0.12 release while we debate which things go where.

Yes, it would be good to allow users to decide which kinds to treat always as "notifications".

labels.description: UI messages, log messages, errors, warnings, feedback
labels.name: messages

title: extui: long pager output may briefly show the "box" panel
